section.title: Futures overview
section.sectiontitle: Use will to talk about a decision made at the time of speaking (including offers and promises). We often use I think / don't think with will in this case.
section.text1: I'll pay you back by the end of the week.
section.text1a: I think I'll pay you back by the end of the week.
section.text2a: I don't think I'll go shopping after lunch.
section.sectiontitle2: Use going to to talk about a plan or intention (but no details have been decided).
section.text3a: I'm going to study law, but I'm not sure where yet.
section.text4a: We're going to go somewhere hot next summer.

section.title: Futures overview
section.sectiontitle: Use the Present Continuous to talk about a future arrangement (when details e.g. about time and place have been decided).
section.text1a: I'm meeting Sonia after my interview in the River Café.
section.text2a: They're taking the six o'clock flight tomorrow.
section.sectiontitle2: Use will to make predictions based on what you know or believe. We often use think, hope, believe, etc., with will in this case.
section.text3a: I think Ben will be the new School President. He'd be really good at it.
section.text4a: I hope United will win the trophy, they deserve it.

section.title: Futures overview
section.sectiontitle: Use going to to make predictions based on what you can see or hear now.
section.text1a: Be careful! You're going to fall off that chair if you lean back like that!
section.text2a: Look at that dark sky. It's going to rain this afternoon.
